results.title: Maps Against the World (2016)
results.credit_line:
Director: Woo-Suk Kang

Writers: Jung-mi Choi (screenplay); Beom-shin Park (novel)

Starring: Seung-Won Cha; Shin Dong-mi; Kim In-kwon
results.brief_description: Director Woo-Suk Kang’s 2016 documentary tells the story of the real cartographer Kim Jeong-Ho who mapped the islands of Korea in the nineteenth century. In a period when only royalty and governments held the knowledge held in maps, Jeong-Ho wanted to make maps to empower ordinary Koreans to mark their land and to travel safely. Maps embody knowledge, in stories and beyond.

constellations_other.name: The narrative power of maps
constellations_other.description: Maps are designed to communicate complex information in a clear manner to aid both navigation and wayfinding and knowledge of place.

results.description: Director Woo-Suk Kang’s 2016 film tells the true story of the 19th century cartographer Kim Jeong-Ho, who mapped the islands of Korea. results.title: Senator Thorpe staunchly opposes fracking in the Beetaloo
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @SenatorThorpe's Twitter, recorded with permission
results.brief_description: Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.
results.title_for_label: Senator Thorpe staunchly opposes fracking in the Beetaloo
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.
description_for_label: Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.

results.brief_description: This video is a remix of footage of tennis from the ACMI Collection, sourced from home movies, commercial videos and professional competitions, and made for display during the Australian Open.

results.title: [Remix: Women in science and technology]
results.brief_description:
This remix is a short film celebrating women in professional roles, including science, technology, aviation, mechanics and farming, sourced from footage in the ACMI Collection.

ACMI gratefully acknowledges the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Dried Fruits Australia, Cargill Australia, Australian Wool Innovation Ltd., Rio Tinto, Elenor Peach, Yolanta Simmonds, Dept. of Employment, John Richardson, Wine Australia and Ivan Gaal.

results.title: [Remix: The Races]
results.brief_description:
This short remix of films about horse racing set to music, takes you through from getting ready and arriving at the track, to placing a bet, the race and the result.

This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to some of the activities around the spring racing carnival that takes place in Melbourne during October and November. It captures the race preparations for both people and horses, and shows the mounting yard, the TAB bets, the race call and a punter finding out the winner.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge donor: Ivan Gaal ( Dir., ‘The Punter’, 1978).

results.title: [Remix: Strike A Pose]
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to people posing for the camera. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring families, fashion models and even a dog, all striking a pose for the camera. On a fashion catwalk, in a parade, on a photoshoot, in a factory or outdoor setting or just the back yard, fashionistas and family folk put their best foot forward from the 1940s to 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Dried Fruits Australia, Karen Wootton, Elenor Peach, Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office, Jenny & Owen Peake, Tony Agapitos and Ivan Gaal.

results.title: [Remix: Hats]
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to hats and how we wear them. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring styles, shapes and fabrics of hats. Whether at the beach, riding a horse, driving a racing car or going for a swim, a fashionable head-covering is a must. Australian fashion’s best styles of hats for men, women and children from the 1930s to the 1980s are shown.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tony Agapitos, Karen Wootton, The Gadsden Family, Elenor Peach, Karen Corry, Jenny & Owen Peake, Gil Brealey & Paul Olson and John Richardson.

results.title: Flash Back: ACMI Collections Mash-up White Night 2017
results.brief_description:
‘Flash Back’, an archival mashup of films and footage from the 1940s through to the ‘80s celebrating the changing face of Australian youth identity and culture.

From rebel youth of the ‘50s, to the ‘70s counter culture revolution and the punk attitudes of the ‘80s, ‘Flash Back’ explores the changing decades through diverse subcultures and the music, fashions and cultural preoccupations that shaped them.

Image: ‘Sharpies: A Gathering’, courtesy Greg Macainsh

Our sincere thanks to filmmakers, musicians and donors for material used in this work. Full details in credits. Edited by ACMI’s Sam Mapplebeck.

results.title: Return of the Sacred Kingfisher Festival 2000
results.brief_description: Each November since the Sacred Kingfisher was seen again in the Merri Creek environment, a festival has been held at CERES Community Environment Park to celebrate the return of this native bird to the area as part of its seasonal migration. The festival, with the participation of local schools and communities, also celebrates the cleanup and revegetation of the Merri Creek environs, and the work of CERES in the Melbourne suburb of Brunswick East.

results.title: Screen worlds : Interview with Ab Rogers
results.brief_description: British designer Ab Rogers is founder and head of a multi-disciplinary studio in London ARD (Ab Rogers Desgin). Ab visited ACMI in December 2008 and the Content Development crew interviewed him in relation to his design and intent behind the Screen Worlds exhibition. He spoke about the tendering process, the challenges of designing for the Federation Square space, his overall approach to design and a brief introduction to the three sections, Emergence, Voices and Sensation.
